query: 给出参考文献时，请忠实给出原文档名，不要翻译成中文，也不要把relation等误当作文档名。关于需要一个标题为：“非洲生物安全态势研判”的报告。分为三个章节：1.非洲生物安全态势 2.非洲生物安全风险点 3.对我国(中国)应对风险及加强非洲国际合作的建议的关键问题是什么？

entities.description: A grouping of informational items including press releases, briefs, and advisories related to health emergency response and preparedness in Africa.
Periodic publication by Africa CDC providing updates and overviews on health emergencies and outbreak responses in Africa between specified dates.

entities.entity: Africa CDC Weekly Brief | 30 June-6 July 2025
entities.description: Weekly briefing by Africa CDC providing updates on health emergencies from 30 June to 6 July 2025.<SEP>Weekly health status and genomic surveillance report from Africa CDC for the period 30 June to 6 July 2025.

Health Security encompasses the systems, policies, efforts, and investments aimed at protecting populations from health threats by preventing, detecting, and responding to infectious disease threats, epidemics, and other health emergencies globally. It involves the capacity of health systems to prepare for, respond to, and recover from health emergencies, which relies on a sufficiently resourced health workforce. In the context of Africa, the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between Africa CDC and the European Union focuses on improving health security across the continent by enhancing disease surveillance, emergency response, and building more robust public health systems. The partnership aims to strengthen Africa CDC’s capacity to ensure effective health security measures throughout Africa, safeguarding populations against current and future health threats.

A specific weekly briefing published by Africa CDC providing updates on health emergencies and related activities for the week of 14–20 July 2025.<SEP>A weekly briefing report issued by Africa CDC detailing health emergency developments and updates for the week of 14 – 20 July 2025.
Various regional, continental, and global organizations working in partnership to support pathogen genomics and public health responses in Africa.

A series of weekly reports and communication briefs issued by Africa CDC which offer updates on health conditions, emergencies, and strategic responses in Africa.<SEP>The Africa CDC Weekly Brief is a recurrent publication that provides updates on health-related developments, strategies, and implementation plans across the continent."|>"Africa CDC Weekly Brief | 14 – 20 July 2025...7 – 13 July 2025...30 June-6 July 2025

Africa CDC Weekly Briefs are a series of recurring weekly briefing documents published by the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) that provide timely updates on health issues, disease surveillance, and outbreak response efforts across the African continent. These briefs serve as important situational updates on public health emergencies, ongoing strategies, and efforts such as outbreak responses and diagnostic decentralization. Specific editions of the briefs referenced include those dated 30 June–6 July 2025, 7–13 July 2025, and 14–20 July 2025, reflecting the continuous commitment of Africa CDC to inform and support health stakeholders with up-to-date information on the continent's public health landscape.

Africa is a continent facing a high burden of infectious diseases and antimicrobial resistance, with mortality rates from antimicrobial resistance surpassing those from HIV-AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. It experiences numerous humanitarian crises and disease outbreaks annually, making it the primary geographical focus of various public health initiatives such as the JEAP initiative. Africa is also served by WHO AFRO and is central to efforts aimed at enhancing public health emergency preparedness and response, particularly in the context of diverse emergencies that are exacerbated by factors like climate change and conflict. Overall, Africa remains the critical region for partnership efforts focused on improving public health emergency preparedness and addressing ongoing health challenges.<SEP>Africa is the continent targeted by the AVMA and related initiatives aiming to increase local vaccine production, improve health security, and strengthen health systems and manufacturing capacity across regions including Central, Eastern, Northern, Southern, and Western Africa."|>"The African Vaccine Manufacturing Accelerator is a Boon for the Continent... Region: Central Africa, Eastern Africa, Northern Africa, Southern Africa, Western Africa

A weekly briefing report released by Africa CDC covering health emergency information for 7 – 13 July 2025.<SEP>Africa CDC's weekly report covering the health and pathogen genomics activities and outbreak updates for the week of 7–13 July 2025.
Regular published updates by Africa CDC that provide information on ongoing public health topics and activities across Africa.

Africa CDC (Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention) is the specialized, continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union dedicated to strengthening health institutions and capacities across Africa. Its primary mission is to enhance disease surveillance, outbreak response, and emergency preparedness to detect, prevent, control, and manage health threats throughout the continent. As a leading public health institution in Africa, Africa CDC plays a central role in building health security and coordinating regional responses to infectious disease epidemics, including mpox, by collaborating closely with African governments and global partners such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the European Union, and Gavi.

Africa CDC actively co-leads initiatives like the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to address disease outbreaks and public health emergencies, while providing technical support, capacity building, and epidemic response coordination. The agency emphasizes genomic surveillance strategies as part of its comprehensive approach to managing public health challenges and strengthening health systems continent-wide.

In addition to its role in disease control, Africa CDC leads and supports critical vaccine manufacturing initiatives, including the African Vaccine Manufacturing Alliance (AVMA), with the goal of increasing local production to meet 60% of Africa’s demand for vaccines, medicines, and diagnostics by 2040. The agency promotes sustainable vaccine development, regulatory harmonization, decentralization of diagnostics, and localization of health product manufacturing to build resilient and self-sufficient health systems.

Operating under the African Union's Agenda 2063 and guided by a strategic plan for 2023-2027, Africa CDC strives to enhance health sovereignty, improve health outcomes, strengthen emergency response capabilities, and foster knowledge-sharing and institutional strengthening across African countries. Through these efforts, Africa CDC empowers Africa’s health security and advances the continent’s ability to manage current and future public health threats effectively.
A collaborative group under Africa CDC, working alongside ASLM, APHF, and Member States to coordinate laboratory and surveillance system strengthening projects across Africa.
Monitoring and analysis of disease-causing agents to detect emerging infections early, guide vaccine development and public health responses, strengthened under the Africa CDC and CEPI partnership.

A thematic focus area emphasizing strengthening surveillance, genomic sequencing, supply stockpiling, and rapid deployment of responders to improve Africa’s ability to manage public health emergencies.<SEP>Emergency Response and Preparedness is a broad and strategic theme encompassing activities, strategies, and measures aimed at responding to and preparing for public health emergencies, particularly health crises and outbreaks such as Mpox in Africa. It involves the rapid and effective mobilization of resources and capacities for Mpox surveillance, containment, and mitigation across the continent. This focus area prioritizes building capacity for timely and efficient response mechanisms, as highlighted in the Joint Action Plan and efforts led by Africa CDC. Overall, Emergency Response and Preparedness addresses the comprehensive and coordinated actions required to manage public health emergencies effectively throughout Africa.
The imminent possibility of a widespread infectious disease outbreak in Africa, underscoring urgency in preparedness.
Livestock production in Africa is at risk from AMR, which could cause a decline of 2.6% to 7.5% annually by 2050, affecting food security and economies.
The mpox outbreak poses a serious public health risk prompting the emergency declaration and demanding coordinated response efforts across Africa.

African Health Sovereignty emphasizes Africa's control and ownership over its health strategies, systems, and products to ensure sustainable, equitable access to quality healthcare across the continent."|>"pledging joint commitments to strengthen... African Health Sovereignty – Africa CDC
Mpox outbreaks threaten global health security by raising the risk of spread beyond Africa, requiring immediate continental-level action.

The African Continent is the geographic focus of the health partnerships and initiatives described, encompassing diverse regions and countries collectively engaged to enhance health sovereignty, pandemic preparedness, and health system resilience."|>"Foundations of our cooperation with the African continent... to build resilient health systems... support global health internationally

entities.entity: Roadmap and targets for AMR in Africa
entities.description: Initiated discussions at the launch event of the African Union Landmark Report on a strategic roadmap and targets to combat AMR in Africa.

The African Union Landmark Report is a publication launched at Africa CDC headquarters highlighting the mortality risk of antimicrobial resistance in Africa and comparing it against other major diseases like HIV-AIDS, TB, and malaria.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency and specialized technical institution of the African Union. It is dedicated to supporting Member States across Africa in strengthening health systems by improving disease surveillance, emergency response, prevention, and control of diseases. Africa CDC focuses on enhancing the continent's capacity to detect, prevent, and respond to health emergencies, including combating deadly diseases such as drug-resistant infections and pandemics. Additionally, the agency plays a key role in communication and information dissemination related to health emergencies and outbreak response. Africa CDC also leads the African Union's public health initiatives, including pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response, aiming to build resilient health systems throughout Africa.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention is a continental public health agency collaborating closely with WHO and the regional emergency hubs to strengthen emergency preparedness and health systems in Africa.

entities.entity: Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa
entities.description: The Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa is a recurring, regularly scheduled media event organized by the Africa CDC. It serves as a platform to communicate updates, information, and responses related to health emergencies and outbreak situations across the African continent. This briefing provides timely and coordinated information to keep the public and stakeholders informed about ongoing health threats and the efforts being undertaken to address them.<SEP>This weekly briefing informs on health emergencies in Africa providing updates and coordination information consequential to epidemic or pandemic threats."|>"Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa

entities.entity: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
entities.description: Africa CDC is the continental public health agency of the African Union mandated to support African member states in building robust health systems, safeguarding health security, and accelerating universal health coverage. It focuses on outbreak and pandemic prevention, health systems strengthening, and local manufacturing of health commodities including vaccines.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
entities.description: Africa CDC is a continental public health agency mandated to address significant health threats in Africa, including coordinating epidemic responses by mobilizing African leaders, governments, and agencies. It declared mpox a Public Health Emergency of Continental Security (PHECS) on August 13, 2024.<SEP>Continental public health agency leading efforts to scale up local vaccine manufacturing in Africa. It hosted a High-Level meeting during the 77th World Health Assembly, led vaccine landscape analysis in partnership with Clinton Health Access Initiative and PATH, and directs initiatives like the African Pooled Procurement Mechanism for improving access and manufacturing.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union. It supports member states in strengthening health systems, improving disease surveillance, emergency response, and disease prevention and control across Africa. Africa CDC leads efforts to enhance epidemic and pandemic preparedness and is responsible for strengthening public health institutions and partnerships throughout the continent. The agency focuses on detecting and responding quickly and effectively to disease threats and outbreaks by implementing data-driven interventions and programs.

Eastern Africa is a geographic sub-region within the continent of Africa that plays a critical and multifaceted role in health surveillance, disease intelligence, and emergency response efforts. It is a focal area for public health initiatives, including preparedness and response activities for outbreaks such as mpox. The region is highly affected by visceral leishmaniasis (VL), accounting for 73% of global VL cases in 2022, making it the primary target of the newly launched VL elimination framework. Eastern Africa is also a key operational zone for humanitarian and development programs, notably the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative, underscoring its importance in addressing crises and enhancing resilience.

In addition, Eastern Africa actively participates in advanced scientific efforts like pathogen genomic activities that support the monitoring and understanding of infectious diseases. The region benefits significantly from coordinated health emergency initiatives and medical response strategies, including its involvement in AU-EU health partnerships aimed at pandemic preparedness and health system strengthening. Overall, Eastern Africa is a vital region for emergency management, public health strategy, humanitarian initiatives, and genomic research, making it central to both regional and global health security efforts.
Occurrences of epidemics or pandemics involving emerging infectious diseases in Africa that Africa CDC and CEPI aim to prevent and respond to through enhanced preparedness and vaccine initiatives.

The health and security agenda in Africa is a strategic priority focused on enhancing local manufacturing capacity for health products to improve medical access, health outcomes, and continental self-reliance.

A strategic framework and long-term vision for Africa’s development, under which Africa CDC’s efforts and the Joint Action Plan with the U.S. government are aligned to promote public health system strengthening and continent-wide progress.<SEP>Agenda 2063 is the African Union’s strategic framework for socio-economic transformation, which is challenged by antimicrobial resistance due to its impacts on health, food security, and sustainable development.

entities.entity: Africa Centre for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: A continent-wide public health institute focused on disease control and prevention in Africa, led by Dr Jean Kaseya, and engaged in advocating for strategic health investments.
Standards and procedures ensuring safety in vaccine development, clinical trials, manufacturing, and deployment, enhanced through the Africa CDC and CEPI partnership to maintain trust and efficacy.

entities.entity: Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response
entities.description: The activities and capabilities focused on anticipating, preparing for, and effectively managing public health emergencies in Africa.

entities.entity: Media Advisory Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa
entities.description: Regular media advisory event for weekly special press briefings on health emergencies in Africa.

Southern Africa is a geographic region in Africa that plays a significant role in regional health and emergency response initiatives, particularly concerning infectious disease outbreaks such as Mpox. It is actively involved in coordinated epidemic response and surveillance efforts, serving as a key area for disease intelligence and outbreak management. The region is part of various health emergency actions and preparedness efforts, including its inclusion in the implementation of the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative. Additionally, Southern Africa is recognized as an important region for pathogen genomic activities, contributing to broader health strategies and outbreak response initiatives across the continent.<SEP>Southern Africa is a geographic region targeted in medical and health emergency initiatives by Africa CDC.<SEP>Southern Africa is included as a geographic focus for AU-EU health initiatives aiming to improve pandemic preparedness and advance health security."|>"Region: Southern Africa

Northern Africa is a geographic region in Africa recognized as a distinct regional zone within various frameworks and initiatives. It plays a significant role in disaster and crisis management, as it is listed within the emergency response and preparedness framework. The region is a key focus area for public health strengthening under the Saving Lives and Livelihoods initiative and is actively involved in broader public health and continental strategy activities. Northern Africa is particularly important for pathogen genomic activities, which highlights its role in health surveillance and epidemiological research. Additionally, the region is concerned with Mpox preparedness efforts and is affected by mpox, participating in continent-wide coordination for preparedness and response actions. Northern Africa is also relevant to health surveillance and antimicrobial resistance monitoring efforts, underscoring its comprehensive involvement in various public health initiatives and regional health security measures.<SEP>Northern Africa is a region within Africa involved in health response activities coordinated by Africa CDC.<SEP>Northern Africa is among target areas for African Union-European Union health programs addressing pandemic prevention, vaccine production, and health systems resilience."|>"Region: Northern Africa
The Africa CDC Website is the online platform providing information on Africa CDC activities, resources, and communications.

Member States refer to African countries affected by or at risk of mpox that participate in the Africa Taskforce for Mpox Coordination to collectively improve disease preparedness, surveillance, response, and control.

Africa is the continent focused on increasing local manufacturing of vaccines, medicines, and diagnostics to strengthen health security by 2040.<SEP>The African Continent is the geographic region focused upon in the partnerships and programs discussed, with aims to improve public health, pandemic preparedness, vaccine production, health sovereignty, and health system resilience.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international public health agency and a global health authority that collaborates closely with Africa CDC, the African Health Regulatory Observatory (AHRO), and other partners to enhance emergency preparedness, disease classification, and health systems strengthening plans across Africa. WHO provides technical support, facilitates information exchange, and coordinates efforts for mpox preparedness and response throughout the continent. Additionally, WHO administers the WHO prequalification process, which serves as a global standard to assure the quality and efficacy of vaccines and health products for procurement agencies worldwide.<SEP>The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international public health agency leading efforts to eliminate visceral leishmaniasis (VL) as a public health problem in eastern Africa through launching new frameworks and coordinating regional health policies.
Dr Salih emphasized the multifaceted threat of AMR beyond health, including impacts on food safety, security, livelihoods, and economies.

A category referring to actions, strategies, and efforts aimed at detecting, managing, and controlling outbreaks of diseases.<SEP>A general category of public health efforts aimed at identifying, managing, and containing disease outbreaks.

entities.entity: European Commission Health Emergency Preparedness and Response Authority (HERA)
entities.description: HERA is a directorate-general of the European Commission focused on preventing, detecting, and rapidly responding to health emergencies, and it collaborates with Africa CDC on strengthening outbreak detection and genomic surveillance in Africa.
National and regional governments across African countries engaged in collaborations to support the implementation of pathogen genomic surveillance and outbreak response.

AMR refers to the growing resistance of microbes to antimicrobial drugs, representing a critical health challenge addressed in AU-EU health collaborations."|>"...strengthening pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health, AMR, digital health, climate and health.<SEP>Antimicrobial Resistance refers to the ability of microorganisms to withstand antimicrobial treatments, posing significant public health challenges which are a focal theme in regional surveillance and disease intelligence efforts in Africa.<SEP>Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is the process by which microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites develop resistance to antimicrobial drugs, leading to higher mortality, treatment failures, and disease spread; it is a critical health threat in Africa linked to misuse of drugs in healthcare, agriculture, and food systems.

entities.entity: United Nations General Assembly High-Level Meeting
entities.description: The United Nations General Assembly High-Level Meeting is an upcoming international forum scheduled for September, expected to address global action plans on antimicrobial resistance, informed by reports such as the Africa CDC's on AMR in Africa.

Emergency preparedness and response involves the surveillance, rapid detection, supply stockpiling, and deployment of first responders to manage disease outbreaks and health emergencies effectively.<SEP>Preparedness and response mechanisms for public health emergencies are a critical focus of the partnership, aiming to enable rapid, coordinated actions to manage outbreaks and health crises across Africa.

entities.entity: Emergency Preparedness & Response Technical Advisory Group
entities.description: EPR-TAG is an independent expert advisory group established by WHO AFRO to provide strategic guidance on public health emergency preparedness and response in Africa; composed of 16 experts from diverse public health fields.
Nyasha Guzha-Chanetsa is Chief State Veterinarian (Public Health & Trade Facilitation) at the South African Department of Agriculture, Rural Development & Environment and an EPR-TAG member.

entities.entity: Emergency Preparedness and Response Technical Advisory Group
entities.description: The Emergency Preparedness & Response Technical Advisory Group (EPR-TAG) is an independent advisory body established by WHO AFRO that provides strategic guidance on public health emergency preparedness and response across Africa.

Malaria eradication is an initial key focus of collaboration between WHO Africa and the BMGF, aiming to leverage data analytics and public health interventions to eliminate malaria in the African region.

relations.description: Africa CDC and WHO collaborate closely to strengthen health emergency preparedness and response in Africa. They provide technical support through mechanisms established at multiple levels, including headquarters, regional centres, and country offices, specifically for the mpox response. Together, they have launched the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP), a strategic partnership aimed at enhancing health systems and combating disease outbreaks across the continent. This initiative reflects their joint commitment to improving Africa's capacity to manage health emergencies effectively.

Africa CDC & WHO welcome UK’s support to address health challenges – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Statement
Africa CDC & WHO welcome UK’s support to address health challenges
The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (
Africa CDC
), The World Health Organization Regional Office for Africa (
WHO AFRO
), and the WHO Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean (
WHO EMRO
) extend their profound appreciation to the United Kingdom government for the recent
announcement
of its transformative commitment to enhancing global health made during the 78
th
session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). The United Kingdom’s dedication to addressing the world’s most pressing health challenges through research, development, and collaboration is both commendable and inspiring.
The allocation of the United Kingdom’s investment of £95 million in tackling deadly diseases in Africa Programme II, will foster partnerships with countries and Africa-based organizations — Africa CDC and WHO — to detect and address future epidemics, combat drug-resistant infections, and address climate-related health challenges. Such collaborative efforts are essential in building stronger health systems and ensuring a more secure future for all.
We also commend the allocation of up to £103.5 million for the development of affordable vaccines and health products, along with initiatives to combat the spread of infectious diseases, particularly during pandemics, as a demonstration of the United Kingdom’s leadership in the field of global health. This investment will undoubtedly contribute to safeguarding the health and well-being of populations worldwide, preventing future outbreaks, and ultimately saving lives.
The commitment to protecting women’s sexual and reproductive health is a crucial step towards achieving a more equitable and inclusive world. By reducing preventable deaths and improving access to care, the United Kingdom is actively working to realize the Sustainable Development Goals and the African Union Agenda 2063 in promoting the well-being of all, regardless of geographic location.
The United Kingdom’s support for research and development in low- and middle-income countries, including advancements in drug administration methods, showcases a commitment to reaching even the most remote areas with life-saving care. This approach aligns with the principles of inclusivity and resilience that are fundamental to the global health agenda.
The commitment to health security by the United Kingdom through international development is evident in its track record of investing in research, development, and healthcare infrastructure. The impact of these efforts, from malaria treatments to diagnostics for drug-resistant tuberculosis, has been significant and has undoubtedly saved countless lives.
We would like to express our deep appreciation for the United Kingdom’s resolute dedication to advancing global health. Their commitment to research, innovation, and international cooperation increases optimism for a healthier and more prosperous world.
We look forward to continued collaboration and progress in achieving our shared global health objectives.
H.E. Dr Jean Kaseya Director General Africa CDC
Dr Matshidiso Moeti WHO Regional Director for Africa
Dr Ahmed Al Mandhari WHO Regional Director for Eastern Mediterranean
2 October 2023
Region
Central Africa
,
Eastern Africa
,
Northern Africa
,
Southern Africa

African region’s first-ever health workforce investment charter launched | WHO | Regional Office for Africa
Skip to main content
WHO Africa
African region’s first-ever health workforce investment charter launched
African region’s first-ever health workforce investment charter launched
06 May 2024
Windhoek –
The World Health Organization (WHO) Regional Office for Africa and partner organizations today launched the region’s first-ever health investment charter that aims to align and drive sustainable investment in the health workforce.
With a bold target of halving the African region’s critical 6.1-million health workforce shortage by 2030, the African Health Workforce Investment Charter will mobilize and align domestic and partner funding to strengthen, grow and retain the continent’s health workforce, especially in rural and primary health care settings.
“Any discussion about the delivery of health care services must acknowledge that, for these services to be rendered and rendered effectively, we need feet on the ground,” said Honourable Dr Saara Kuugongelwa-Amadhila, Namibia’s Prime Minister. “For the health professionals to do their work effectively, they must be well resourced and capacitated in the best ways possible.”
In addition to shortages, the African region faces many other health workforce challenges, including, rising unemployment, excessive out-migration and low quality of training. Low health investment and limited prioritization of the health workforce have critically exposed health systems. Investment in health, especially from domestic sources, is still low and inadequate for many countries to meet the universal health coverage and ensure health security
“The numbers of Africans who have left the continent in search of greener pastures in other parts of the world are staggering. It is a matter that needs to be addressed as a top priority for African governments and indeed all those who wish to see a shift in the historical as well as current trends,” said Honourable Dr Kalumbi Shangula, Minister of Health and Social Services of Namibia.
The charter launched today brought together the health workforce investment efforts of all stakeholders, including national governments, the private health sector, civil society, external financing institutions and development partners in Africa.
“By investing in the health workforce, we not only address the challenges within the sector but also generate dividends in education, employment and gender equality,” said Dr Matshidiso Moeti, WHO Regional Director for Africa. “These investments will contribute to our sustained efforts in attracting more resources and improving the quality of our health workforce.”
Investing in the health workforce will have positive spin-offs in the form of decent jobs, particularly for women and youth who often face barriers to employment. By providing opportunities for education, training and career progression, the Charter will immensely contribute to the economic empowerment of these demographics and fundamentally support inclusive economic growth.
Additionally, health labour force investment also brings multiple returns for health and economies, increasing life expectancy and job creation, while accelerating countries towards the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and universal health coverage.
For every US$1 invested in health and sustaining the jobs of health workers, the potential return is as much as US$9. It has also been demonstrated that half of all economic growth globally over the past decade resulted from improvements in health, and that for every added year of life expectancy, the economic growth rate is boosted by 4%.
“Studies show that investments in the health sector yield substantial economic returns, estimating a nine-to-one return on investment. The new narrative that we are promoting is to transform the health sector to move from liability to an asset for the economy of our countries,” said Dr Jean Kaseya, Director-General of the Africa Centre for Disease Control and Prevention.
The Africa Health Workforce Investment Charter was inaugurated in Namibia during the Health Workforce Investment Forum being held from 6 to 8 May 2024. Efforts will continue to be made to engage multisectoral stakeholders and partners on their experiences and achievements, and mobilize commitments, partnerships and investments to deliver on the principles and actions enshrined in the investment charter.
Click image to enlarge
For Additional Information or to Request Interviews, Please contact:
Collins Boakye-Agyemang
Communications and marketing officer
Tel: + 242 06 520 65 65 (WhatsApp)

Africa CDC and EU Join Efforts to Improve Equitable Access to Health Products and Local Manufacturing for Africa – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and EU Join Efforts to Improve Equitable Access to Health Products and Local Manufacturing for Africa
The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the European Union Commission signed an agreement to support access to health products and local manufacturing in Africa as part of the Team Europe Initiative on Manufacturing and Access to Vaccines, Medicines, and Health Technologies. The agreement was signed by H.E Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director-General of Africa CDC, and Jutta Urpilainen, European Commissioner for International Partnerships, during the Global Gateway Forum in Brussels on October 25-26. This agreement complements the Team Europe Initiative on Manufacturing and Access to Vaccines, Medicines, and Health Technologies (TEI MAV+) for Africa.
The MAV+ initiative of Team Europe partners with African nations to strengthen local pharmaceutical manufacturing. It aims to improve access to quality health products, aligning with UN Sustainable Development Goal 3.8. The Global Gateway Forum brings together global leaders to promote infrastructure investment for Sustainable Development Goals. Furthermore, the European Union is contributing €134 million to support sustainable implementation of national plans in six African countries, fostering local manufacturing and equitable access to health products. These efforts align with the shared development objectives and geopolitical priorities of both the European Union and the African Union, complementing existing initiatives such as the African Union-European Union Innovation Agenda, the Africa CDC-PAVM Initiative, the EU Global Health Strategy, and Global Gateway.
Jutta Urpilainen, European Commissioner for International Partnerships, stated, “With its Global Health Strategy, the EU is committed to strengthening health systems and securing global chains around the world, while boosting our partners’ strategic autonomy, promoting universal health coverage, and preventing future health emergencies. These additional Global Gateway support measures will bring in more actors from the private sector and civil society. Notably, they provide targeted support to our African partners in building capacities of local production of pharmaceuticals and medical technology.”
The key objectives of this initiative encompass skills development through higher education and vocational training, promoting the sustainability of the private sector, fostering local ecosystems, supporting entrepreneurs and SMEs, ensuring quality assurance along national supply chains, facilitating research and development (R&D) for new or improved health products, promoting technology transfer with a focus on local organisations and shared African and European interests, strengthening regulatory processes at the country level in coordination with regional actions involving the European Medicines Agency (EMA), WHO, AUDA-NEPAD, and the African Medicines Agency (AMA), driving innovation and digitalisation to enhance access to medicines, and enhancing managerial skills, country leadership, and ownership.
H.E. Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director-General of Africa CDC, expressed, “The signing of this agreement solidifies our shared vision in nurturing a coordinated global response to global public health challenges. This action-oriented partnership aims to advance the New Public Health order and expand local manufacturing in Africa.”
About Africa CDC
: Africa CDC is an autonomous health agency of the African Union which supports Member States in their efforts to strengthen health systems and improve surveillance, emergency response, prevention and control of diseases. Learn more at:
https://africacdc.org

Africa CDC and France sign Memorandum Of Understanding to Strengthen Public Health Systems in Africa – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and France sign Memorandum Of Understanding to Strengthen Public Health Systems in Africa
11 September 2023, Addis Ababa
– The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the government of France signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) today to strengthen their cooperation in public health. The MoU was signed by H.E Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director-General of Africa CDC, and Rémi Maréchaux, Ambassador of France to Ethiopia, at a ceremony held at the Africa CDC Secretariat Offices in Addis Ababa.
The MoU aims to strengthen Africa CDC’s efforts to build more robust public health systems and improve health security across the continent. Key areas of collaboration under the MoU include strengthening Africa CDC’s capacity; supporting the development of national public health institutes; enhancing disease surveillance and emergency response capacities; promoting local manufacturing of vaccines, diagnostics and therapeutics; supporting workforce training; and fostering research partnerships between French and African institutions.
“The signing of this MoU solidifies our shared vision in nurturing a coordinated global response to global public health challenges. This action-oriented framework aims to advance the New Public Health order, enhance health workforce development, and strengthen public health systems for the benefit of all African citizens,” said H.E Dr. Jean Kaseya at the signing ceremony.
This MoU builds on France’s longstanding support for public health in Africa. France played a leading role in launching the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator and has donated 10 million vaccine doses to the AVAT mechanism and 48 million doses to 40 African states, mainly through the COVAX initiative aimed at equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines. The French Development Agency provided a €50 million line of credit to Afreximbank for the AVAT payment facility, enabling vaccine purchases by Uganda, Burundi, DRC and Egypt. The AFD has committed over €500 million to health programs in Africa through its ” Santé en Commun ” (Health in Common) initiative. France also provides technical expertise to Africa CDC in infection, prevention and control (IPC) and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH).
France is a major contributor to Team Europe Initiatives that align with Africa CDC’s priorities, like strengthening pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity on the continent with over €70 million mobilized so far. France also supports regional health projects in West and Central Africa that reinforce Africa CDC’s diagnostics, surveillance, and regulation objectives.
The signing of this MoU signals France and Africa CDC’s continued commitment to mutually tackling major public health challenges in the  interest of public health, safety, and security of all African citizens,”
For media inquiries, please contact:
Mikaele THOMAS
Press department at the French Embassy Tél : 01 11 40 00 25 Mél : Mikaele.thomas@diplomatie.gouv.fr
PO Box 1464, Addis-Ababa Yeka   Kebele : 01102, Addis Abeba

About the African Union:
The African Union is a continental body that leads Africa’s development and integration in close collaboration with the 55 Member States, the Regional Economic Communities and African citizens. The AU’s vision is to accelerate progress towards an integrated, prosperous, and inclusive Africa, at peace with itself, playing a dynamic role in the continental and global arena, effectively driven by an accountable, efficient, and responsive Commission. Learn more at: http://www.au.int/en

,
H.E. Stella KYRIAKIDES
“
An ever-closer partnership between the African Union and the European Union is indispensable for public health. We want to work more closely with our African partners on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health and anti-microbial resistance, as well as the health effects of climate change. These are core objectives for our EU Global Health Strategy and the foundations of our cooperation with the African continent. We are now at a critical stage of the negotiations on the pandemic agreement and the international health regulations, with which we would provide new multilateral solutions to common challenges. The EU is committed to conclude the negotiations by May, a responsibility equally shared by all nations. I am pleased that the African Union and EU are joining voices and taking concrete steps to support global health internationally.
”
Africa CDC Director General,
H.E Dr Jean Kaseya
“As we navigate the complexities of global health, Africa is on the path towards self-sufficiency through equitable access to medical products. Africa’s target of producing 60% of vaccines by 2040 through the Africa CDC underscores our commitment to health sovereignty. Through strategic partnerships like the EU-AU collaboration, we accelerate our capabilities, leveraging expertise and resources to build resilient health systems and strengthen Pandemic preparedness.”
Specific outcomes of the high-level conference include the following concrete engagements:
Working Arrangement between Africa CDC and the European Commission to best implement the expanded strategic AU-EU Health partnership;
The European Commission and the Belgian Presidency announced additional TEI MAV+ funding for the advancement of the African Medicines Agency;
The announcement of procurement commitments by Global Health Initiatives to buy in Africa for Africa;
Three additional Team Europe Initiatives on health were launched: Health Security using a One Health approach, Digital Health, and Public Health Institutes;
The Team Europe Initiative (TEI) on Social Protection was launched;
Work product leads for Team Europe and Team Africa were confirmed;
A new programme ‘SafeBirth Africa’ to support improved access to innovative life-saving commodities for sexual and reproductive health in Africa. The programme will be implemented by Unitaid and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), supported by a financial contribution of €20 million from the EU budget under the Team Europe Initiative on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights that was launched in Kigali in December 2022;
An expanded AU-EU High Level Steering Meeting (HLSM) at DG-level will jointly oversee regional heath TEIs.
-END-

Statement
Joint Statement on the Africa CDC and United States New Joint Action Plan
On November 28, on the sidelines of the Third International Conference on Public Health in Africa in Lusaka, Zambia, the frica Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the U.S. government announced a Joint Action Plan to advance a shared vision to strengthen public health systems and deliver improved health outcomes in Africa.
The Joint Action Plan outlines key activities between the Africa CDC and U.S. government to achieve the objectives identified in the Memorandum of Cooperation to Promote Public Health Partnership, signed by African Union Commission Chairperson Moussa Faki and Secretary of State Antony Blinken in March 2022.
The Joint Action Plan represents a significant step toward stronger and deeper Africa CDC -U.S. collaboration, building on both Africa CDC and U.S. health investments and partnerships across Africa. It will facilitate institutional strengthening, expert exchanges, and knowledge-sharing in support of the African Union’s Agenda 2063 and the Africa CDC Strategic Plan 2023-2027. Additionally, it will promote integrated health systems, strengthen public health emergency response capacity, enhance clinical and laboratory systems, and expand innovation and local manufacturing of health products.
The Africa CDC and U.S. government intend to convene regular meetings of technical experts in Addis Ababa and Washington to operationalize, review, and update this Plan to support shared public health needs and global health security requirements.
28 November 2023
Theme
Emergency Response and Preparedness
